Comment: Let's do some political math!  Let's say Canada becomes the 51st US state:  Populating of Canada: 40M  Population of California: 39M  So Canada would get 2 senators and 52 members of the house  Not bad, but can we do better?    Lets' figure it another way:  Canada has 10 provinces and three territories for a total of 13.  Let's say each province/territory is admitted as a separate state  That's + 26 senators for Canada, and (for simplicity) assume the same 52 members of the House.  That's better.  But we're not done yet...     Yet another way:  \- All 343 member of the Canada House of Commons become members of the US House  \- All 105 members of the Senate of Canada become members of the US Senate.  That sounds pretty good!    I'm surprised that PM Carney did not point out these annoying facts when he recently met with 47
Author: Catspaw129

Like, this whole 51st state shit is so godamned stupid. You aren't gonna have a single state the size of the rest of the 48 mainland states.   At this point I'm expecting us to annex Canada, create 10 new states, giving us 20 senators, and because the combined backlash will be so immense, we can almost immediately, cordially split the country in two and ride off into the sunset while we leave the red states to rot in their little 'utopia'.

Comment: Being fair, the entire thing would be fixed if we just expanded the House of Representatives.  Canada has 343 parliament members for 40 million people.  The equivalent for the US would be if the US House of Representatives had 3000 reps.  Right now it has 500 (for 350 million people).  Obviously fitting that many people right away would be untenable, but at the very least it should be doubled, and probably just making permanent a Wyoming rule (the size of the house shall be set based on the total population of the united states divided by the total population of the least populous state).  The issue is 1 House Rep represents 500,000 people for Wyoming.  In California, 1 House Rep represents 900,000 people.  Because the size of the senate + house is used to determine number of electors in the electoral college, Californians have their vote diluted.
Author: jnads

Comment: As a Canadian, the extent to which your government bodies are just completely open to bribery and corporate ‚Äúsponsorships‚Äù is wild to me. That‚Äôs the big one. There‚Äôs also the concept that a lot of the way it was set up relies on having good-faith people in government is a real bad one-two punch - those two things in combination result in basically exactly what you see today - a mega-billionaire more or less bought the election through social media influence and quite possibly actual election interference, and then all of the government bodies that could hope to regulate and prevent them from going crazy are all more or less subject to the executive branch. The Supreme Court, which isn‚Äôt necessarily, still has judges in it that are pushed through by the senate, which is inherently political, so it too is subject to extreme political bias.  The US system allows for all of this corruption pretty openly and relies purely on good faith and upstanding folks in government to prevent it.  Most other parliamentary systems have some level of flaw there, but it‚Äôs not nearly the same. Already a more-than-two-party system helps a lot, but also there tend to be a lot more regulation and rules around the whole bribery thing. That helps a lot.

Comment: The original idea with checks and balances is that each branch will be jealous of the other branches' powers. So even if you have bad actors, they were supposedly going to act in the interest of the branch of government they were in for the sake of their own personal power, and that would prevent any one branch from becoming all powerful.  Then political parties formed almost immediately and threw that entire theory out the window.  I guess that's what you get when you have a bunch of slave traders, slave owners, and racists make a new government that primarily benefits them and then ignore the rotten foundations for 250 years.
